The '''Ettenmoors''' were a high barren<ref name="N">{{HM|N}}, entry '''Ettendales''', p. 770</ref> region that lay on the western side of the [[Misty Mountains]] north of [[Rivendell]] and south of [[Angmar]].<ref name="Map">{{FR|Map}}</ref> The river [[Hoarwell]] flowed from its sources in the Ettenmoors<ref name="Flight">{{FR|Flight}}, p. 200</ref> to the southwest.<ref name="Map"/>

The Ettenmoors were also called the '''troll-fells''',<ref name="Flight">{{FR|Flight}}, p. 200</ref> probably because the region was inhabited by [[Trolls]].<ref name="NM">{{NM|P3xvii}}, Text 1, note 12, p. 366</ref> The Ettenmoors included the land of the [[Ettendales]], which consisted of valleys reaching up into the foothills of the [[Misty Mountains]].<ref>{{HM|UI}}, entry ''Ettendales'', p. 188</ref>

The realm of [[Rhudaur]] lay between the Ettenmoors in the north and the [[Angle]] between the rivers [[Hoarwell]] and [[Bruinen|Loudwater]] in the south.<ref name="Eriador">{{App|Eriador}}, p. 1040</ref> It is speculated that [[Mount Gram]], from where a host of [[Orcs]] [[Battle of Greenfields|attacked]] [[the Shire]], was located in the Ettenmoors.<ref>{{HM|AME}}, pp. 75, 80</ref>

==History==
Since the [[Elder Days]], [[Trolls]] concentrated especially around the Ettenmoors, and they increased during the rule of [[Angmar]], that was founded in the north.<ref name="NM"/>

In {{SA|3320}} when the realm of Arnor was founded by the [[Dúnedain]],<ref>{{App|SA}}, entry for the year 3320, p. 1084</ref> the Ettenmoors probably became part of Arnor.

When the kingdom of [[Arnor]] split into three successor kingdoms after the death of King [[Eärendur (King of Arnor)|Eärendur]] in {{TA|861}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 861, p. 1085</ref> the Ettenmoors probably became a part of the kingdom of Rhudaur.<ref name="Eriador"/>

In {{TA|1975}} after his defeat in the [[Battle of Fornost]]<ref name="TA1975">{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 1975, p. 1086</ref> the [[Witch-king]] of [[Angmar]] fled with the remains of his troops to the north to reach his realm of Angmar and the shelter of [[Carn Dûm]],<ref name="Gondor">{{App|Gondor}}, entry for King Eärnil II, p. 1051</ref> but was pursued to the Ettenmoors<ref name="TA1975"/> where he was overtaken by the cavalry of [[Gondor]] and a force from Rivendell led by Glorfindel.<ref name="Gondor"/> After the fall of Angmar, the Trolls retreated to the east of the [[Misty Mountains]] but returned in the 28th century and even expanded westwards as far as the [[North Downs]].<ref name=NM/>

It is possible that [[Chieftains of the Dúnedain|Chieftain]] [[Arador]] was slain by trolls in this area<ref>{{App|Tale}}, p. 1057</ref> in {{TA|2930|n}}.<ref>{{App|North}}, entry for Chieftain Arador, p. 1038</ref>

Around [[November]] or [[December]]<ref name="South">{{FR|South}}, p. 274</ref> {{TA|3018}},<ref>{{App|Great}}, entry for the year 3018, Dezember 25, p. 1092</ref> scouts from [[Rivendell]] investigated the Ettenmoors for any activities concerning [[Nazgûl|Ringwraiths]] or other servants of [[Sauron]], but they came with no warning news.<ref name="South"/>

In October {{TA|3018}} [[Gandalf]] after his battle with the Ringwraiths at [[Weathertop]] [[Gandalf]] fled riding on [[Shadowfax]] to the north in the hope of drawing off some of the Ringwraiths. He had to send Shadowfax away in the Ettenmoors, because he was not able to ride among the rocks there.<ref name="Council">{{FR|Council}}, p. 264</ref>

==Etymology==
{{seealso|etten}}
The name ''Ettenmoors'' consists of ''[[etten]]'' and ''moor'' ("high barren land").<ref name="N"/>

"Fells" means hills or moorland, thus the "troll-fells" were hills in which [[trolls]] lived.<ref name=RC>{{HM|RC}}, p. 183</ref>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
In the "first phase" of ''[[The Fellowship of the Ring]]'', map sketches label the source of Hoarwell as [[Dimrill Dale]](s), but when the name was displaced, the region was renamed Hoardale, changed to "Entish Dales" or "Entish Lands". This was before [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] conceived the [[Ents]] of ''[[The Two Towers]]'' and the adjective "entish" directly refers to Old English ''eōten'' "giant"<ref>{{RS|1XId}}</ref> (see also [[#Etymology|Etymology]] section).

Later Tolkien decided to change it into "Trollfells" (capitalized without a hyphen): he wrote on a map: "Alter Entish Lands to [Trollfells > Bergrisland >] Ettenmoor". This is also the first mention of Ettenmoor(s) in the legendarium.<ref>{{TI|Map}}, p. 306</ref>

==Inspiration==
The name ''Ettenmoors'' is similar to the land of [http://narnia.wikia.com/wiki/Ettinsmoor Ettinsmoor] of [[The Chronicles of Narnia|Narnia]] by [[C.S. Lewis]]. In ''The Silver Chair'' Lewis mentions that it is inhabited by [http://narnia.wikia.com/wiki/Ettin Ettins], giants who often play the game of Cockshies, throwing rocks at a gorge, much like the [[giants|stone giants]] in ''[[The Hobbit]]''.

==Portrayal in adaptations==
===The Ettenmoors in adaptations===

'''2001: ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring]]'':'''
:A [https://www.ccgtrader.net/card/5976/ettenmoors card] from ''[[The Lord of the Rings Trading Card Game]]'' identifies one of locations in which [[Arwen]] evaded the [[Nazgûl]] as the Ettenmoors.

'''2002-5: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Roleplaying Game]]'':'''
:The Ettenmoors are the homeland of the ''[[Etten]]s'' who resemble [[Hill-trolls]], but they possess "not one but two long heads".<ref>{{D|Fell}}</ref>

'''2007: ''[[The Lord of the Rings Online]]'':'''
:The Ettenmoors is the region where Player vs Monster Player play takes place, pitting the "Army of [[Angmar]]" against the "Coldfells Army" of the [[Free Peoples]]. The two factions each have a home base which cannot be entered by the opposing side and a secondary base which can be assailed but not captured. Between them are five major control points: the keeps of "Lugazag", "Tirith Rhaw", and "Tol Ascarnen", the "Isendeep Mine", and "Grimwood Lumber Camp"; as well as several smaller outposts, all of which can be captured by either side.

:Other sites of interest include the [[Hobbits|Hobbit]] village "Hoarhallow", its [[Orcs|Goblin]] counterpart, "Grothum", as well as dens of [[bears]], [[eagles]], [[Dragons|drakes]], [[Wargs]], and other beasts that align with one side or are hostile to all.
